snippet: A surge of brain activity in dying rats may hold an explanation for the realistic visions experienced by some human victims of cardiac arrest, researchers say.
abstract: Jimo Borjigin study in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences suggests that surge of brain activity in dying rats may hold explanation for vivid, realistic visions experienced by some human victims of cardiac arrest.
lead_paragraph: A surge of brain activity in dying rats may hold an explanation for the realistic visions experienced by some human victims of cardiac arrest, researchers say.

headline.main: The Stuff of Those Visions in Clinical Death
headline.print_headline: Brain Science: The Stuff of Those Visions in Clinical Death

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
